 -1 - L. THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. Background 1.1 Poland possesses extensive transport networks and facilities. Related to country area, 313,000 km2, and population, 38 million, transport densities are at an average European level. The system includes about 360,000 km of roads of which more than 60% are paved (109 km/I 00 km2, EU: 128 km/100 km2), some 24,000 km of railway lines, of which 49% are electrified (EU: 38% on average), three major ports with international traffic (Gdansk, Gdynia, Szczecin-Swinoujscie), close to 4,000 km of inland waterways, and four airports with scheduled intemational connections as well as a large number of domestic airports (see IBRD Map 27435). 1.2 The present situation in the sector is shaped by two main factors: the legacy of the past and the ongoing restructuring of the economy. In Poland, as elsewhere in Eastem Europe under the former system, there was a general lack of competition, pricing was unimportant, and enterprises were vertically integrated, providing their own technical and social services. There was a high degree of centralization in decision-making. In the transport sector this led to a small number of very large organizations, some with hundreds of thousands of employees. A deep transformation of objectives, policies, legal and regulatory frameworks, structures and operations is now underway to enable the sector to break away from state owned, centrally controlled monopolies geared to meet mainly physical targets with scant regard for quality, financial and other efficiency criteria. At the same time, modemization of certain parts of the sector and a geographic redirection of emphasis for closer integration with the economies of Westem Europe are of high priority. 1.3 This transformation has already achieved notable results. Partly as a consequence of the transformation but also because of the severe drop in industrial output experienced during the first years of the process, there has been a significant drop in traffic, especially for the railways, but the ports have also been affected. However, following the mounting recovery of the national production system, an upward trend seems to have taken root, in particular as far as intemational traffic is concerned. B. Foreign Trade 1.4 During the last five years, Polish exports reached a level in the range between US$13 and US$17 billion. The highest level was reached in 1994 with US$16.9 billion, a 25% increase over 1993. Imports of goods increased sharply over the period and reached US$17.8 billion in 1994, an increase of 12% over 1993, but a total increase of 52% compared with 1990. 1.5 The major import products are those of the electro-engineering industry, the chemical industry, and the energy sector. Imports from the chemical industry make up for 18% of total imports, whereas petroleum products and gas make little more than 10%. 1.6 For the coming period it can be expected that Polish exports will focus on commodities which take advantage of low labor costs, as in the textile and clothing industries, woodworks and
 -2- metalworks industries. Export opportunities for agriculture and labor-intensive industries could further be enhanced through Poland's accession to the European Union. 1.7 These evolutions will have direct consequences for the demand on the transport system. In particular, since more than 55% of the Polish foreign trade (in tons) already goes through the Polish ports--which is foreseen to reach 65% in 2005--, the effectiveness of the port sector, and the reliability and efficiency of its connections with other land transport networks, will clearly be prominent factors in fostering the national economic development in the years ahead. C. Transport Sector Administration 1.8 The Ministry of Transport and Maritime Economy (MTME) has overall responsibility for the transport sector within the government structure. The Ministry's responsibility covers road, rail, air and maritime transport and infrastructure, plus some related activities such as a few minor shipyards located within the port areas. The legal arrangements and actual operating arrangements between the Ministry and its dependent entities vary, covering the full range from purely administrative units such as the General Directorate of Public Roads (GDDP) to enterprises in which the Government retains control. In recognition of the importance of separation of the functions of policy setting, ownership and operations management, some of those enterprises, including the three main port authorities, were transformed in joint-stock companies in 1992, the shares of which are fully owned by the Ministry of Ownership Transformation pending their expected total or partial sale to external pubfic or private investors. Annex 1 shows the administrative structure of the Polish transport sector. 1.9 MTME's main functions are: (i) policy formulation; (ii) elaboration of sectoral budgets; (iii) allocation of budgetary funds and subsidies between subsectors and enterprises; (iv) overall supervision of entities such as PKP, GDDP, and Port Authorities; as well as a variety of regulatory activities, including safety regulations. D. Sectoral Issues and Policies 1.10 The Transport Policy Paper issued by MTME in July 1994, and subsequently approved by the Council of Ministers in the fall, spells out the priorities of the national transport policy. Among those are clearly stated the requirements (i) to remove bottlenecks in the transport system, and (ii) to achieve high economic, social and environmental effects, so as to strengthen the competitiveness of Polish transport organizations, and hence of the national economy. 1.11 The main issues still confronting the transport sector can be listed as follows: restructuring of state-owned transport organizations, level and employment structure, competition and modernization. Restructuring of State Owned Transport Organizations 1.12 The restructuring process has been underway for several years already, and many new independent enterprises have been set up out of former large state monopoles. The Bank's First Transport Project contributed to this process, in particular in the railways and roads sectors. One common way of dealing with public companies has been a two-step approach, whereby (i) they were
 -3- first converted into joint-stock companies, the shares of which being fully owned by the Ministry of Ownership Transformation during a specified time period, and (ii) at the expiration of this transitory phase, sold in part or in full to external investors. This has been applied to the Port Authorities (para.2.10). The second step of this process has proven more difficult than the first one and reaching agreement on the conditions under which investors will participate has required considerable time. Level and Employment Structure 1.13 Present shortcomings of the Polish transport system include excessive employment levels in some subsectors. Such a situation exists mainly in rail transport, but generally the branch employment structure does not fit the functional requirements of a modem transport system. Differences with the branch employment structure in the EU are highlighted in the foUlowing table: Table 1.1 Employment Structure in Transport in Poland and in the EU in 1991 (%) Subsector EU Poland Railway Transport 16.1 51.4 Inland Water Transport 0.4 0.6 Road Transport 45.1 27.8 Ports and Maritime Transport 3.9 5.0 Air Transport 6.3 1.1 Auxiliary Activities 28.2 14.1 Source: Transport Policy Paper, July 1994 This points to the need to lower considerably the employment level in rail transport, and to a lesser extent in sea transport, whereas the employment share in auxiliary activities (freight forwarding, shipping agencies, logistics) should significantly increase. Although this adjustment process is already underway, much remains yet to be done. Competition and Modernization 1.14 The Government's expressed aim, as reiterated in the Transport Policy Paper, is to increase competition in the whole transport sector. The restructuring of public enterprises, as mentioned above, is one element of this strategy. Both GDDP and PKP previously procured goods and services available from their subsidiary units without competition, but are now inviting bids from these and other enterprises. In the port subsector, most operating units have been formally separated from the Port Authorities, but real competition between port services providers is still very much in its infancy. 1.15 The modernization of the transport system also requires a better coordination between the different transport modes. Combined road-rail transport has already met with some success in Poland, but the necessary physical facilities need upgrading, and the organizational arrangements are
 -4- not yet optimal. The Bank's Roads Project has begun addressing these issues through a Pilot Program under implementation. Combined transport can also include a better use of the waterway network, which has badly suffered of neglect in maintenance in the past. An important step in improving the development of efficient transport services would be to improve the physical connections between different transport networks at critical transit points, among which the seaports of national importance figure prominently. E. Transport Investments 1.16 A significant shortcoming of the sector in recent years has been the low level of investment, from both public and private sources, compared with the total domestic investments. Indeed in 1992 the total national transport investments amounted to 4.4% of the total domestic investments, even though the total transport assets accounted for 12.4% of the country's national assets. Whereas in the EEC countries there are about US$0.09 of annual investment per tkm, there are 15 times less in Poland (US$0.006). The ongoing First Transport Project (Loans 3193-PO and 3194-PO, US$4.8 and 145.0 millions respectively, Staff Appraisal Report 843 1-POL of April 5, 1991) and the Roads Project (Loan 3564-PO, US$150.0 million, Staff Appraisal Report 11226-POL of February 11, 1993) aim to support the restructuring and modernization of the railways and highways respectively as well as to improve the overall traffic safety and to develop combined transports. The two Projects are progressing well, with the First Transport Project now close to completion. Policy reform and restructuring have been implemented faster than foreseen, and disbursements are following the expected schedule.
 -6 - II. THE PORT SUBSECTOR A. Port Facilities 2.1 The Polish seashore comprises two maritime regions, the Eastern one centering around Gdansk and Gdynia, and the Western one around Szczecin and Swinoujscie. The ports of Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin-Swinoujscie handle together over 95% of the Polish maritime traffic (52 million tons in 1994), the remaining being shipped through a number of smaller ports like Police, Stepnica, Kolobrzeg and Elblag. Generally speaking, although some of the port facilities are near the end of their economic life, the two maritime regions have ample port capacity to accommodate the traffic volumes forecasted up to 2005, as far as the overall throughput is concerned. However, restructuring and modernization of existing facilities will be necessary to accommodate changes in traffic patterns and structure--increase in ferry traffic, for instance--and new functions such as value-added services. 2.2 Total present port throughput capacity, depending on the evolution of the traffic structure between dry bulks, liquid bulks, and breakbulk/general cargo, stands between 70 and 80 million tons per year, which is potentially sufficient, as a whole, to cover traffic requirements until 2005 (para.2.16). However, changes in the distribution of traffic flows, for instance from export to import, may need significant conversion works of the corresponding facilities. Similarly, the expected growth of general cargo, container and ferry traffic will demand adjustments of the existing physical infrastructure. The various dedicated and common use port facilities have potential capacity surpluses and shortfalls, which will have to be adjusted in order to make the best economic use of the available assets. 2.3 Gdansk, with its North Port being the deepest of the Baltic Sea, can accommodate ships up to 150,000 tdw and is the best equipped facility for dry and liquid bulk cargo handling, with ample space available to cater for future developments (see IBRD Map 27439). Gdynia, apart from its smaller scale bulk facilities and its general cargo areas, is equipped with a modern container terminal, the Baltic Container Terminal, which started operations in 1979 and is the only genuine container port in Poland (see IBRD Map 27438). Szczecin operates a mix of breakbulk and bulk facilities, most of them being rather old and in a great need of repair (see IBRD Map 27436). Swinoujscie is basically designed as a drybulk port, but is now diversifying into breakbulk cargoes in addition to its industrial role (see IBRD Map 27437). Swinoujscie, Gdynia, and Gdansk operate ferry and roll-on/roll-off terminals, the two former being by far the most significant. A summary of port physical facilities is given in Annex 2. 2.4 Hinterland connections are in a poor state, in particular the road accesses, and consequently severely hamper port throughput efficiency. The marked shift already underway from rail to road for inland transport compounds this situation, which may jeopardize the
 -7 - efficiency gains realized within the ports, in particular for time-sensitive flows such as ferry and container traffic. The proposed Project will concentrate on this aspect (paras.2.27 and 3.3). B. Administrative Framework 2.5 From the end of the Second World War the main Polish ports have been managed by dedicated State Companies. The ports of Szczecin and Swinoujscie have been managed as one single company to date, whereas the ports of Gdansk and Gdynia after having been managed by one port authority until 1954, have since then been managed separately. These port companies were acting as executive branches of the Ministry of Transport. 2.6 Nautical and maritime tasks, including navigation safety and maritime accesses maintenance, have been executed by Urzad Morski (Maritime Bureau) in Gdynia, Szczecin, and Slupsk, subordinated directly to the Minister of Transport and Maritime Economy. 2.7 The port ownership and management structure was thus strictly centralized. Moreover, the major ports also acted as home bases for Polish Ocean Lines, and other state owned shipping companies. All seaborne transports were also centrally planned. As a consequence, Polish ports possessed a monopolistic position with regard to Polish foreign trade. They operated mainly on behalf of the national economy and as transit points for cargoes from Czechoslovakia and Hungary, within the COMECON framework. 2.8 The transportation of goods via Polish ports to and from the hinterland was mainly done by train. There was therefore no compelling reason to develop the road infrastructure near the ports and in the port cities. As the majority of Polish waterways were neglected and few are navigable, inland water transport has not been developed on a large scale. Train transport was, and for bulk commodities still is, the major land carrier of seaborne freight to and from inland destinations. The poor state of the road network leading to the ports is partly a consequence of this situation. 2.9 Moreover, relations between port cities and their ports were weak. This, and the domination of rail transport, resulted in a situation where ports and cities developed largely in isolation. This situation is again reflected in the many poor and badly maintained access roads to the various ports. This is therefore the reason why the Project proposes to focus on the port road access aspect as a matter of priority. Present Legal Framework 2.10 In order to separate policy setting, ownership and management functions in a market economy, the state port enterprises were transformed between May and November 1992 into Joint Stock Companies of the State Treasury. The main legal basis for such a status can be found in the Law on Privatization of State-Owned Enterprises, dated July 13, 1990. The State,
 - 8 - represented by the Treasury, is the legal owner of 100% of the capital of the Port Authorities Companies, with the formal rights with regard to the use of capital and assets devolved to the Ministry of Ownership Transformation. In a later phase, the law provides for the transfer of shares of the joint stock companies into the hands of their final shareholders, the nature of whom has to be defined in the new Ports Law to be enacted (para.2. 12). 2.11 During 1991 three Joint Stock Companies were established: Port Authority of Szczecin-Swinoujscie, with a total staff of 5,000; Port Authority of Gdynia, with a total staff of 6,700; Port Authority of Gdansk, with a total staff of 4,000. In this new structure the port enterprises became increasingly independent from the central government. They gradually moved from operating companies under the direction of MTME to full-scale port authorities provisionally linked to the Ministry of Ownership Transformation. In the meantime they began separating the operating units from the management bodies, with the intention to set up private commercial operating companies (paras.2. 17/24). 2.12 Providing the sector with a definitive official legal framework is a central issue. The new Ports Law has been under preparation since 1991, and a final draft, in line with the Bank's strategy in the sector, has been discussed between the various ministries involved for more than a year, before being officially approved by the Council of Ministers on October 17, 1995. It now has to be approved by Parliament, where it is expected to be passed without major difficulties, which should take place within three to four months. The preparation of the Project contributed to the ideas and thinking behind the draft law. As a result of the draft law discussions, both MTME and the Port Authorities have already started behaving in the spirit of the law, therefore beginning to dispel the uncertainty as to legal and regulatory aspects, which clearly was hampering further sector development. 2.13 The main thrust of the draft Ports Law is to provide for the new Port Authorities to act as "landlords", in charge of managing the public infrastructure assets, while the port commercial activities would be carried out by separate private operators, fully independent from the Port Authorities. This concept, which is now broadly accepted among the port community, appears as the most adequate arrangement. It must be complemented by a clear definition of the regulating role to be played by MTME, which according to the draft law, will formally recover its monitoring function over the sector as a whole, and will represent the State Treasury in the Port Joint Stock Companies. The technical assistance component of the proposed Project will provide help to work out practical implementation arrangements and regulations once the Ports Law is passed (para.3.21). The principles of the proposed law are widely accepted and the Polish authorities are preparing for their implementation. However, even in case of unforeseen
 -9 - delays with the new law the proposed Project will contribute to meaningful and high return developments of port activities. It should also be noted that Polish ports already operate in an international competitive context. In addition, domestic competition between ports in Poland is significant. Overall Sector Organization 2.14 The future organization of the sector will therefore consist of: MTME, in charge of overall sector monitoring and regulation, through two specific departments: the Department of Shipping and Seaports, directly responsible for supervision of the Ports Authorities and assessment of their development programs; and the Department of Sea and Inland Waterway Administration, responsible for navigation safety through the Maritime Offices, and for legal management of the port public assets; the Port Authorities, in charge of the management of port infrastructure facilities, and of the strategic development planning; the private operating companies, in charge of all commercial operations in the port areas. C. Traffic 2.15 The port sector has been affected by many of the same forces that have influenced the economy in general. With respect to physical throughput there has been a substantial decline. Between 1980 and 1991 traffic has been reduced from 66 mt to 44 mt with imports cut in half but exports only marginally reduced. The 1993 traffic recovered to above 48 mt, an order of magnitude maintained in 1994 with about 52 mt. Gdynia, Gdansk and Szczecin handle most of the breakbulk cargoes moving through Polish ports. Gdynia dominates the container traffic, while the bulk trades are shared predominantly between Gdansk and Swinoujscie, Gdynia and Szczecin handling a more limited, although significant, proportion. A summary of 1994 port traffic for the three main ports is presented in Annex 3. 2.16 The forecasts available today, elaborated on the basis of anticipated domestic economic growth and commodities market analysis, amended to take into account the possible traffic diversion by other modes of land transport to and from neighboring countries, point to around 62 mt of total port traffic for 2000, and around 78 mt for 2005. The commodities expected to have important growth are general cargo, container and ferry traffic, with the overall general cargo flows more than doubling between now and 2005. The container traffic, in particular, is slated to register the most impressive growth, increasing by about 200% over the
 - 10- period, while the ferry traffic would follow with a 130% growth rate. Global traffic forecasts are presented in Annex . D. Port Organization 2.17 Within the relative legal vacuum created de facto since the formal transfer of the administrative ownership of ports to the Ministry of Ownership Transformation and the preparation of the new Ports Law, the ports themselves started to privatize parts of their operations. In doing so, all three major ports developed different policies. 2.18 The Port of Gdansk, simultaneously with its establishment as a Joint-Stock Company, formed 28 limited liability companies out of former departments of the port enterprise. As a first stage, the Port Authority kept 45% of the shares of these companies, the other 55% being owned by the workers. In a second step, in 1993 the Port Authority transferred its 45% share to the individual companies, now consequently 100% employee-owned. The operating companies own mostly light handling equipment and vehicles, whereas the superstructure located on their dedicated areas is rented out by the Port Authority. These companies employ a total of some 2,200 staff. 2.19 As a result of this transformation process, the Port Authority is now a smaller organization with limited tasks, all commercial activities being left to the operating companies. The Port Authority of Gdansk employs 400 people, and is responsible for infrastructure development and maintenance, managing the lease and renting agreements with the operating companies, and providing them with basic utilities services. 2.20 Although this is formally a genuine privatization process, the result in the field is still remote from what should be expected from private commercial port operations, in particular as far as competition is concerned. All stevedoring companies, for instance, work under the umbrella of the Commercial Sea Port of Gdansk, an additional private company belonging to the port workers (80%) and the companies themselves (20%). This umbrella company actually does all the marketing for the stevedoring companies, based on a common tariff policy, and distributes the work to keep everyone busy, which is nothing but a new monopoly situation, in fact a workers monopoly. Furthermore, as a consequence of the way they were established, these operating companies are generally greatly undercapitalized, unable to maintain and develop their asset base, and it is likely that many would collapse if put in the midst of a true commercial competition. 2.21 The Port of Gdynia took a cautious approach towards the privatization of its operational activities. It has for some time been operating within the organizational framework of the original state enterprise, while preparing for progressive divestiture of commercial operations. As a first step, seven entities were earmarked for separation from the Port Authority, and internally restructured, shedding in the process about 2,000 jobs. In a second
 move, two operational entities were hived off into independent companies in 1994, the Baltic Container Terminal and the Baltic Grain Terminal. Two more are slated to follow in 1995. The port and the independent companies together employ 4,700 staff. 2.22 For the time being, these companies are still fully owned by the Port of Gdynia, but with the objective to open up their shareholding structure to allow local and foreign private investors to take equity stakes, and finally to control the companies. This is a requirement of the new Port Law, which will state that the Port Authorities should not have any commercial interest in the operating companies. 2.23 The Port of Szczecin-Swinoujscie, when established as a Joint-Stock Company, formed 17 limited liability companies out of former departments of the port enterprise, as did the Port of Gdansk (16 remain now, following a merger). The Port Authority has kept 45% of the shares of these companies, the other 55% being owned by the workers. All fixed assets, including equipment, are still owned by the Port Authority, which leases them to the operating companies. Moreover, the Port Authority has a decisive say in the companies' tariff policy, negotiates the contracts with customers on behalf of the companies, and coordinates the distribution of work between the different companies. These companies employ around 3,800 staff, and the Port Authority about 500. 2.24 Clearly, this process stops short of any genuine privatization or commercialization of operations in a competitive market situation. To comply with the new Ports Law soon to be enacted, the Port Authority will have to withdraw from the operating companies. But their present condition, with regard to finances, marketing, restructuring and management skills, would prevent most of them from surviving without the support of the port administration, which is actually managing them. Thus a process of further restructuring has to be foreseen. E. Port Planning and Investment Program 2.25 The Transport Policy Paper spells out the priorities for the maritime transport subsector, which as far as the ports are concerned, are as follows: (a) improve the competitiveness of Polish ports and shipping services; (b) develop ferry connections between Polish ports and ports around the Baltic sea; (c) ensure greater navigation safety and ecological protection of the coastal environment. Apart from upgrading the technical capacity of the ports, the policy will also aim at completing the institutional reform process, to achieve complete separation between port ownership,
 - 12 - management and commercial operations, to end monopoly situations, and to support the development of multimodal transport technologies. 2.26 Consequently, and taking into account the significant potential reserve of capacity already in place, investments in ports should serve to upgrade and modernize the services provided, while refraining from increasing the global throughput potential. This potential, however, must be adjusted to cope with the changes in foreign trade and traffic structures and patterns. In doing so, priority must be given to investments towards improvement in unitized cargoes' handling and transit, development of logistics services, and activation of efficient sea- land combined transport operations. 2.27 The proposed Project will address these priority issues. In improving road accesses to the ports, it will contribute to enhance the service offered to unitized cargoes like containers and goods shipped on ro-ro and ferry carriers. It will contribute to improve safety of navigation in implementing a vessel traffic management system between Szczecin and Swinoujscie, and to safety of road transport by diverting heavy trucks away from city centers to better direct connections between ports and inland transport networks. F. Port Finance and Cost Recovery 2.28 Before the economic reform process was launched, the central government decided, directly or indirectly, on the most important financial aspects in port management: investments, tariffs, cargo allocation, costs of production factors. The combination of centrally determined tariffs and cargo allocation implied that the ports had no influence over the volume of cargo they handled, and therefore could not influence their total revenues by using competitive pricing. Moreover, as the cost of production was by and large determined by the central government there was little room left for the ports themselves to manage their financial performance. 2.29 Today the ports are formally joint-stock companies under the supervision of the government, but it is not clear how far the monitoring tasks to be logically performed by MTME are actually carried out, in particular as investments and tariffs are concerned. The situation should become clearer when the new Ports Law, which includes provisions on the relationships between the ministry and the ports on these matters, is finally enacted. In addition, the role of the central government with respect to cargo allocation and costs has now practically ended. The cargo is allocated between ports on a commercial basis, and the costs are market related, with the result that the financial performance of the ports is now to a large extent determined by their management. 2.30 Although the profits of the port sector are reportedly lower than in the seventies, positive results are still made. Compared with the former situation the share of the gross profit that the central government takes has decreased: the income tax presently stands at 40%, instead
 - 13 - of 60% in the past, and ports pay a dividend, halved in 1993, which actually has more a character of interest than of dividend, being linked to a percentage of the share capital and not to the performance of the company. However, under the present tax and dividend rules a significant part of the gross profit--between 50 and 70% depending on ports--is still paid to the government. Port Revenues 2.31 Port revenues consist of charges for services in the areas of navigation, use of berths and cargo and passenger operations. Objectives 3.1 The objective of the overall port sector modernization program is to contribute to the development of an efficient administrative/managerial structure and improvement of physical facilities in the ports of Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin-Swinoujscie, so that they will provide efficient services in competition with other ports serving their potential hinterlands. It is also expected that the enactment of a new Port Bill in the meantime will have set the stage for effective dealings with the port authorities. 3.2 The Project would fit within the Country Assistance Strategy defined in the CAS report dated October 20, 1994, as a medium-sized transport infrastructure Project aiming at bridging some missing links in basic infrastructure facilities, and which would be limited to investments not likely to attract private financing (CAS para.41), while helping setting the stage for further private sector participation in port operations. 3.3 The objectives of the proposed Project are therefore to improve: physical access to the ports; and management capacity in the ports of Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin- Swinoujscie. Achieving these objectives will strengthen the ports' capacity to provide efficient services and to connect more effectively with domestic inland transport networks, thus enhancing the competitiveness of the whole transport chain. In addition, the Project would assist the Borrower, through technical assistance and training, in implementing the new institutional set-up now being devised for the port sector. In view of the present overcapacity and the unclear future situation of ports in the Baltic and their hinterlands, the two Projects will focus on clearly identified needs for the Polish ports and would thus not contribute to a general port overcapacity in the Baltic Sea region.

However, due to natural phenomena combined with poor maintenance over the past years, the breakwaters have ceased to function as such and have turned into massive and irregular heaps of stones. The situation is further worsened by the significant deposits of silt and sand carried by the tide and the river waters. The river bed is now heavily silted. Furthermore, ships beyond 176 m are only allowed to sail through the fairway during day-time, because of the lack of safety monitoring system, which causes significant additional downtime to most ships calling at Szczecin (see IBRD Map 27440).

Background 1.1 From the end of the Second World War the main Polish ports have been managed by dedicated State Companies. The ports of Szczecin and Swinoujscie have been managed as one single company to date, whereas the ports of Gdansk and Gdynia after having been managed by one port authority until 1954, have since then been managed separately. These port companies were acting as executive branches of the Ministry of Transport. 1.2 The port ownership and management structure was thus strictly centralised. Moreover, the major ports also acted as home bases for Polish Ocean Lines, the national shipping company. All seabome transports were also centrally planned. As a consquence, Polish ports possessed a monopolistic position with regard to Polish foreign trade. They operated mainly on behalf of the national economy and as transit points for cargoes from Czechoslovakia and Hungary, within the COMECON framework. 1.3 In order to separate policy setting, ownership and management functions in a market economy, the state port enterprises were transformed between May and November 1992 into Joint Stock Companies of the State Treasury. The State, represented by the Treasury, is the legal owner of 100% of the capital of the Port Authorities Companies, with the formal rights with regard to the use of capital and assets devolved to the Ministry of Ownership Transformation. In a later phase, the laAk provides for the transfer of shares of the joint stock companies into the hands of their final shareholders, the nature of whom has to be defined in the new Ports Law to be enacted. 1.4 The future organization of the sector will therefore consist of: MTME, in charge of overaD sector monitoring and regulation, through two specific departments: the Department of Shipping and Seaports, directly responsible for supervision of the Ports Authorities and assessment of their development programs, and the Department of Sea and Inland Waterway Administration, responsible for navigation safety through the Maritime Offices, and for legal management of the port public assets,
 Annex 6 Page 2 of 4 the Port Authorities, in charge of the management of port infrastructure facilities, and of the strategic development planning; the private operating companies, in charge of all commercial operations in the port areas. H. Objectives of the Technical Assistance 2.1 The main thrust of the draft Ports Law is to provide for the new Port Authorities to act as "landlords", in charge of managing the public infrastructure assets, while the port commercial activities would be carried out by separate private operators, fully independent from the Port Authorities. This concept, which is now broadly accepted among the port community, appears as the most adequate arrangement. It must be complemented by a clear definition of the regulating role to be played by MTME, which according to the draft law, will formally recover its monitoring function over the sector as a whole, and will represent the State Treasury in the Port Joint Stock Companies. 2.2 The main objective of the Technical Assistance Program is to help the Polish Administration, and in particular the Ministry of Transport and Maritime Economy (M`IME), to work out the practical implementation arrangements, and related detailed regulations, required once the Ports Law will have been passed, which is expected to occur in the first half of 1996. 2.3 Additional objectives include helping the three Port Authorities of Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin-Swinoujscie, implement the provisions of the new law and of the detailed regulations referred to above. In particular, this refers to the need to formally separate port management from commercial operations, and to monitor market activities in order to protect public interest. IMI. Contents of the Technical Assistance The Technical Assistance will focus on the following: 3.1 MTME (a) help the Directorate of Seaports and Shipping and the Directorate of Maritime Administration and Inland Waterways to elaborate the detailed regulations required to allow the Ports Law to be practically implemented; (b) help to establish the financial relationships setup between MTME and the Port Authorities, and in particular:
 Annex 6 Page 3 of 4 i. the specific conditions under which investments in port developments or maintenance could benefit from partial or total national budget funding, and the nature of these investments; ui. the definition of the financial contribution from the Port Authorities to the national budget; (c) help the Directorate of Seaports and Shipping to work out market management regulation for commercial port activities, with the aim to secure an open access for outside private providers, while ensuring overall safety in port operations and working standards; (d) help define the standard reporting requirements expected from the Port Authorities, in terms of financial statements, traffic and operations statistics, development and investment policy, tariff policy, (e) help the Directorate of Maritime Administration and Inland Waterways to elaborate the working relationship setup between the Maritime Offices (Urzad Morski) and the Port Authorities, in particular: i. for maintenance dredging management and contracting; ii. for navigation aids management and connections with broader port management information systems. 3.2 Port Authorities (a) help Port Authorities manage the separation of the commercial operations from their public management responsibilities: i. financial advisory services to assist in preparing and implementing divestiture of commercial activities; ii. manpower management assistance in dealing with possible staff redundancies; Hi. financial management assistance in devising new tariff policy and tariff schedules in line with a landlord port structure: leases, concession fees, utility services pricing, general access and protection dues;
 Annex 6 Page 4 of 4 (b) help set up market monitoring regulations for supervision of private operators, management of the open access policy to the market of port services, prevention of monopoly abuses, and enforcement of safety standards and environment protection rules; (c) help upgrade port management systems to comply with the reporting requirements to be enforced by MTME, in particular in the field of traffic and operations statistics. IV. Implementation Period 4.1 The Technical Assistance program will be implemented throughout the Project implementation period, the MTME component having to be initiated first, as soon as the Ports Law is enacted, to allow the Port Authc,rities to adjust their policies thereafter. Implementation is foreseen to last at least two years following the enactment of the Ports Law. 4.2 The Technical Assistance will be complemented by a Training programn managed by the Department of Seaports and Shipping in MIME, and including the various areas of interest listed in Annex 7. The Training program will be implemented in a flexible way, depending on actual needs and opportunities, all throughout the life of the Project.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Port Access and Management Project for Poland is to improve: (I) physical access to the ports of Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin-Swinoujscie; and (II) management capacity of these ports. The project's components include improving: (A) road accessibility, which will involve completing: (i) access to the Szczecin Central Port area, (ii) the Wolin road renovation, and (iii) the Gdansk North Port connection; (B) maritime accessibility, which will implement the Vessel Traffic Management System; (C) coastal protection, specifically that of the Wisla Smiala Outlet; and (D) technical assistance and training, which will focus on helping: (i) the Ministry of Transport and Maritime Economy, and (ii) the port authorities.
